chapter.title: The Flows tab
chapter.para: The Flows tab is used to manage the flows of a particular line. Notice the similarity of this tab with the Projects and Lines tab.

mediaobject.caption: Flows tab. The interface is split in two parts: left and right panels.

chapter.para: The default view of the right panel of the Flows tab contains a summary of the current flow. This view presents the input/output files, the programs and the parameters altered by the user (different from the provided values). Additionally, problems in the flow assembly are warned in this window. To go to the summary view, just select (single click) a flow.

tip.para: You can perform searches on the flow summary by pressing CtrlF.

section.title: The menus list
section.para:
In a menu was defined as a set of one or more programs that can process data. These menus are accessible in the Flows tab, trough the button menu list
presented in the toolbar.

After clicking the menu list button, a pop-up window is shown with a list of categories. All menus registered inside GêBR are divided into these categories, which can be expanded by clicking the
icon on the left.

note.para: A menu can appear more than once in the unfiltered list, since it can pertain to any number of categories.

section.para: By typing parts of the menu title or description in the text box on the top, it is possible to filter the menus list. This eases the task of finding or discovering a menu when its domain is known. For example, it is possible to search for menus related to migration (see ).

mediaobject.caption: The image shows the menus list being filtered by migration. All menus that have the word migration in its title or description are shown.

section.title: Creating flows
section.para: To create a flow, follow the steps:

step.para: In the Projects and Lines tab, check that some line is selected;
Go to the Flows tab, then left-click on .
The Flow Properties dialog will appear. Fill in the basic information of the flow and then click OK.

section.para: After these steps, the flow will be appear on the left side of the main window. The right side will show information about this flow, like its title, description and modified date.
The menus list will automatically appear in a pop-up and the user will be able to assemble the flow (see).

tip.para: It's possible to alter the position of the flow in the list by dragging the flow with the mouse to the desired position.

section.title: Assembling the flow
section.para: In GêBR, a flow is a sequence of operations defined by the user. These operations, also called programsProgram, are organized into the following categories according to their purpose:

listitem.para: Gain, NMO, Stack and Standard Processes

section.para: After the flow has been created, a pop-up appears with several menus and is possible assemble the flow:

step.para: Choose one of them and include it in the flow with a double-click.
To specify an order to the programs, simply drag and drop the desired programs.
Inserted program comes in an enabled state (unless they have required parameters).
Some programs have required parameters. To edit or to alter the default parameters, consult .
To change the program status, right-click over it and choose the first option, Enable/Disable (for more information, see ).

important.para:
To run a flow all the programs listed in the Flow Sequence box must be enabled (
). Otherwise the flow will not be executed as expected.

section.para:
The flow is ready to be executed. Click on
or on
to do it (for more information, consult ).

After the flow has been assembled, it will be visible on the left side of the main window when the Flows tab is selected. The Details box, found on the upper right side of the main window, shows information about the selected flow. The Flow Review box shows a brief of the flow and contains information like input,output and log file, flow's programs and some of its parameters.

section.title: Editing program's parameters
section.para: Program's parameters compose a set of initial configurations defined by the user.
To edit program's parameters follow the steps below:

step.para:
Select the program from the list and click on
on the toolbar, or just double-click on the program. The Parameter box will appear on right side of window over the Flow Review box.
Edit the program's parameters. Notice that each parameter vary greatly both in size and type.

tip.para: Click on the Help button (bottom right corner of the dialog box) to view the program's documentation. This will be certainly useful when the user is editing the programs parameters.
Click on the Reset button to return to default configurations.

step.para: All changes are saved automatically, and to close the Parameter box, simply change selection on left side.

section.title: Changing a program's state
section.para:
Alternate between these states by using two methods: right-clicking on the program and then select the desired state from the context menu or using the shortcut
Spacebar to change the states of the selected programs.

tip.para:
It's possible to select several programs whose state is desired to change by holding
Ctrl Click or
Shift Click .
Changing a program state does not alter its parameter configuration. This way, alternate between states is an operation completely safe.

important.para:
Disabled programs (
) will be ignored when the flow runs. This way, the user can enable and disable parts of the flow.

section.para: To associate an input, output and error file to a flow, follow these steps:

mediaobject.caption: Select the Flow Editor Tab. In the Flow Sequence box it's possible to edit the input, output and log files for this flow sequence.

step.para: Select a flow, in the Flows tab.
Below the selected flow, the programs and entries with input, output and log files will be shown. To edit files paths, just double clicking on them.

Type in the path (important folders can be consulted/choosen by typing <) or click on
to browse for the file (see ).

section.para: For using the folders associated to the line, choose them like above or use the feature of autocomplete of the important folders of this line. For more information, see .

section.para:
When a path is chosen for the flow's input/output, their file paths will appear in entries, indicated by the icons
and

note.para: If necessary removing a set from the list, select them by pressing right-click and then click on Exclude.

section.title: Copying, pasting and deleting flows and programs
section.para: The clipboard provides the popular set of tools known as copy and paste. A flow (or set of flows) can be copied to the clipboard and paste back to the same line or to other lines. In the same manner, a program (or set of programs) can be copied to the clipboard too, and can be paste to the same flow or to other flows.

To copy flows or programs to the clipboard, first select them with the mouse, and then use the button
or press the usual shortcut
Ctrl C . After copying the user can paste it by clicking on the button
or by simply using the shortcut
Ctrl V .

To delete a flow (or set of flows) and a program (or set a programs), select them then click on
.

tip.para:
It's possible handle several flows at once by holding
Ctrl Left-click or
Shift Left-click .

caution.para: GêBR does not ask for confirmation before deleting programs from a flow.

section.title: Snapshot of a flow
section.para: There are situations when working with GêBR it will be useful to use an existing flow as a basis to create new flows. For example, to experiment with flows that are only slightly different from one another, however without having to discard or modify the original flow.

A way to do this is to copy and paste the flow (see the section . Another way is to take a snapshot of the original flow, through a snapshot, GêBR stores the settings of a flow so it's easy come back to it later.

section.title: Taking a snapshot
section.para: All snapshots of the flow are presented in the flows tab. To take a snapshot of a flow:

step.para: Select the flow and left-click on More button on Toolbar.

Then click on
to take a snapshot.
It's really necessary to write a description of the snapshot in the dialog box to identify this saved state later on.
Left-click on OK to save your snapshot

tip.para: Useful keybinds are available here: Ctrl+S takes a snapshot of the selected flow.

section.para:
To see the saved snapshots, just left-click on
in the details of a flow.

section.title: Snapshot actions
section.para: A user that uses different versions of the same flow may also be benefited by the use of snapshots. An option would be to save many different flows, one for each version, which drawback is the pollution of the flows tab. Another option, using the feature above, is taking a snapshot of each version of the flow.

mediaobject.caption: In this view, the user can perform various actions in the snapshots, like revert, delete and run

section.para: The graph indicates from which version each snapshot was derived from. The start of arrow indicates the origin and the end indicates the modified version.

caution.para: GêBR always preserves the setup of the flow. Even if the computer was turned off, this list will be recovered when GêBR is opened again. However, if the flow was deleted all the saved states will immediately disappear forever.

section.para: Through a right-click over the target snapshot, the user has the option to Revert, Delete or Run it. The right-click over the current stage (Now) allows the user to Run the current flow or to take a snapshot thereof.

In this view, also is possible use multiple selection just click over several snapshots and the actions are disposable through the right-click over a snapshot. After to choose several snapshots and the action, this action will be applied in all selected snapshots.

To deselect a snapshot is as easy as select one, the user just need to click over the undesired snapshot. Also is possible deselect all the selected snapshots by clicking on the white area in this view.

listitem.para: If a snapshot of a flow was taken and for some reason undesired modifications were made to it, is possible to revert to another one through double-click on that. Whenever a snapshot is reverted, the dialog Reverting modified flow will appear.

mediaobject.caption: Two option are avaliable to proceed.

itemizedlist.listitem: Take a snapshot: a dialog to input a description will appear, where is possible save this new snapshot.
Proceed discarding changes: GêBR will simply revert to the chosen snapshot without saving the current state.

tip.para: If the current state was previously saved, GêBR recommends that the user click on Proceed discarding changes, in the dialog box Backup Current State, as to avoid a bloated snapshot view.

listitem.para: The delete of a snapshot is a permanently action. After do that, this snapshot will disappear and cannot be recovered.

GêBR deals with the idea of origin of the snapshot. In the graph of the figure, 'B1' and 'B2' come from 'B' which, by its turn, comes from 'A'. If the user deletes 'B', GêBR will consider 'B1'and 'B2' as originated from 'A'.

Running a snapshot is like running a flow (see ). The advantage of doing this is the possibility of executing a snapshot without having to revert to it. Thus, saved flows can be tested without changing the current one.

example.para: Take the program SU Plane for that example. That program create common offset with up to 3 planes, and there are two possible output options for that flow: image plot, using program X Image or postscript image, using PS Image.

To solve this issue (two possible outputs for a flow) without the need to create two separate flows with small differences, it is possible to take two snapshots: one for image plot, and the other for postscript.

To do that, following the steps below:
Assemble the flow with two programs, SU Plane and X Image.
Takes a snapshot of this flow, with some description like "Common offset with image plot".
Remove the program X Image of the original flow, and add a program PS Image, with some output file like "plot.ps".
Takes a snapshot of this new flow, with description like "Common offset with postscript image".
Now, with only one flow can run two different plots for the data generated from SU Plane.

section.title: Importing/Exporting a flow
section.para: Although GêBR maintains all the data, sometimes it's necessary to copy the flow to files for sharing.
In the window Save flow, navigate to a desired directory and type a name for the file (GêBR will automatically determine the extension flw). To do so:

step.para: In case of Import, the user must first select a flow (or see , if one does not exist).

Select the tab Flows and left-click on
to import or on
to export.
Navigate through the files and select the flow that is desired to be imported/export.

section.para: In case of Import, the imported flow will be listed along with any other flows of the selected line. Otherwise, in case of Export, the file containing the exported flow will be created.

section.title: Executing a flow
section.para: After being triggered, the execution can be followed in the same window or, for more detailed information, in the Jobs tab (see and ).

tip.para: More than one flow can be selected together and executed. To make a multiple selection, click over the flows, while Ctrl is pressed or use the arrow keys while Shift is pressed.

section.title: Run
section.para:
By clicking on
, the job will be triggered with the following settings:
In case of multiple flows, the default is executing one after another.
The flow (or flows) selected is (are) going to be executed immediately.
If the flow is parallelizable, the job will be dispatched on all group's nodes. If not parallelizable, it's necessary to choose the best node.
Parallelizable flows are going to be splitted by nominal capacity (total number of cores). If not parallelizable, the flow will not be splitted. (For more information, see ).
The flow execution is going to compete for resources with other processes. (For more information, see ).
It is a fast way to execute, skipping the configurations of the Run and Setup.

note.para: Some execution configuration (like group's nodes, number of tasks splitted and priority) can be saved using Setup and Run. That configuration is going to be a new default for basic Run. (For more information, see )
Useful keybinds are available here: Ctrl+R runs the selected flows one after another; Ctrl+Shift+R runs the selected flows parallely (keybind activated just if multiple flows are selected).

section.title: Run and Setup
section.para: Many execution details can be set before triggering a job. After setting, click on Run to execute the job.

By clicking over
, it can be set:
How jobs are going to be executed. This option just appear if multiple jobs are selected for running (multiple execution).
One after another: flows can be executed one after another, in the order they are on the flows list. Each flow awaits for the end of the previous job to be executed.
Simultaneously: flows are executed parallely, all of them at the same time. It is just possible if there is no dependency between flows.
Whether jobs must wait for some task or not. Jobs can be triggered after the ending of another task or immediately by clicking the execution button.
Where jobs must be dispatched. Nodes or set of nodes can be choosen to process the jobs. A special option is the Choose automatically. It allows the maestro to search for the least overloaded nodes or set of nodes. If the use changes this parameter, GêBR shows the number of cores of the choosen group.
The number of tasks settled to split the jobs. This parameter is valid only when there is a parallelizable job among the selected jobs. The nominal capacity is given by the number of cores, according to the choice of the group's nodes. For non-parallelizable jobs, this parameter is automatically set to 1. For more information, consult .
How a job must compete with other processes on the system. In overloaded nodes, this option can make all the difference because jobs will have less priority than other processes running on the system. For more information, consult .

note.para: Itens 3, 4 and 5 can be saved for future executions by checking Save Preferences.

example.para: On a multi-core system, create a flow according to the following steps:
example.procedure:
Insert a loop with thirty steps (see
for further details about loop).
. Insert a sleep program with parameter set of one second.
Open the Execution detailed window, and set the minimum number of cores (one core) to execute the flow and Press run.
Execute step three again, but now with the maximum number of cores (nominal capacity). .
example.para:
It can be seen that:
For the minimum number of cores, the flow lasts thirty seconds to be executed. That is because the only core is responsible for the thirty sleeps step.
For the maximum number of cores, the flow is executed much faster. For more than thirty cores, it lasts only one second. On a thirty cores system, each sleep is executed by one core, so that a fast distributed execution is possible.

This flow is parallelizable only because one step of the loop is totally independent of another, so, in a system with multiple machines and multiple cores, this flow can be divided to execute all their tasks on the same time, making the execution faster. Therefore, all flows with the same characteristic can take advantage of it.

section.title: Flows with loops
section.para: The notion of a loop refers to a series of commands that continues to repeat over and over again, possibly changing a little, untill a condition is met. For example, suppose the user needs to generate one plot for each of a set of functions. One option is to create many flows, each one based in a function, that generates the plots. Another simpler option would be to create a single flow that, for each function, generates a plot. The loop program allows it in GêBR.
The LoopLoop is a program from the category Loops that has a totally different usage compared to the remaining programs of GêBR. Here these differences are presented.

Whenever the program Loop is added, it appears on the top of the flow. That happens to indicate that the flow is going to be executed more than once, according to the parameters set for the program. (see for further details).

mediaobject.caption: Screenshot of program Loop, added to a flow and properly configured.

section.para: After the Loop is added, a new variable, the iter, is available (see ). The value of this special variable is modified on each iteration (increasing or decrementing), according to the parameters set.

mediaobject.caption: Screenshot of the edition from parameters of Loop program, with a simple example of parameters setting.

section.title: Following the execution
section.para: After a flow has been sent to execution, the status and output of the job can be followed in the same window, still in the Flows tab. A bar in the botton of the window will appear to keep a history of the last jobs dispatched for execution and to switch among the results of the different jobs.

Each job execution is represented in the bar as a button, composed by:
an icon, that represents the status of the execution; and
an identifier, which is associated to the number of executions of that flow.

Different from the Jobs tab, in the Flows tab it is presented just a quick view of the job. Indeed, the aim of this features is not to present a full view of the job, but to avoid the switching of tabs to follow jobs. The arrow takes to the Jobs tab, where a complete view of the flow execution can be consulted.
When multiple flows are dispatched for execution, instead of staying in the same window, GêBR automatically switches to the Jobs tab, where all the executions can be seen all together.
